chunk.name: Frontispiece
chunk.description: This is the frontispiece

chunk.name: Dedication
chunk.description: This is the dedication

chunk.name: Preface
chunk.description: This is the preface

chunk.name: Biography
chunk.description: This is the biography of Bernardino Baldi

chunk.name: Works
chunk.description: This is the list of the works by Bernardino Baldi

chunk.name: The definition of mechanics
chunk.description: Mechanics is a disclipline that, using geometry and natural substances, can create amazing things

chunk.name: What mechanics is about
chunk.description: It's about heavy and light. Heavy can be of two types: in accordance to nature and contrary to nature. Light can only be in accordance to nature. When they are in accordance to nature, heavy moves towards the center of the hearth, and light moves from the center of the heart. Then Baldi deals with the gravity center. The gravity center can be of three types: linear, plan and solid. Then quotes authors who have dealt wiht this argument. Then says that exists also a lightness center, but it is neglected by Mechanicians because it's quite useless to their purposes. Then says how Heron and Commandinus defined the concept of gravity center. Then gives his own definition. Then gives examples of the gravity center in the three different dimensions. Then he discusses the case when the gravity center of a geometrical figure falls outside its own shape. Then he explains that there is more than one kind of gravity center, such as one in accordance to nature, one contrary to nature, and one as a result of the mixing of both ones. Then he gives an example for each of these three kinds.

chunk.name: Mechanical instruments
chunk.description: Here he starts discussing the Mechanical instruments. First of all, he wants to estabilish how many the fundamental types are. He says that Aristotle brings all the instruments back to the lever and the balance. Almost all the other mechanical scholars seem to set the number of the fundamental instruments to five: Vectis, Trochlea, Axis in Peritrochio, Cuneus, Cochlaea. Thus he decides to analyse all these five features. But first he discusses the position of Aristotle, according to which lever and balance are the only two fundamental instruments. He makes a difference between libra and statera, which Aristotle doesn't.

chunk.name: Mechanical instruments
chunk.description: Here he explains the importance of the cirlce and its properties in the aristotelian mechanical theories.

chunk.name: Quaestiones
chunk.description: 35 questions of mechanics

chunk.name: Question 1
chunk.description: Why are larger balances more accurate than smaller ones?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 2
chunk.description: If the cord supporting a balance is fixed from above, when after the beam has inclined the weight is removed, the balance returns to its original position. If, however, it is supported from below, then it does not return to its original position. Why is this?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 3
chunk.description: Why is it that small forces can move great weights by means of a lever? And, being a lever a weight itself, why isn't it easier to move weights wihout a lever (that means a minor weight) rather than with it?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 4
chunk.description: Why do the rowers in the middle of a ship contribute most to its movement?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 5
chunk.description: Why does the rudder, which is small and at the end of the vessel, have so great power that it is able to move the huge mass of the ship, though it is moved by a smaller tiller and by the strength of but one man, and then without violent exertion?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 6
chunk.description: Why is it that the higher the yard-arm, the faster the ship travels with the same sail and the same wind?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 7
chunk.description: Why is it that, when the wind is unfavourable and they wish to run before it, they reef the sail in the direction of the helmsman, and slacken the part of the sheet towards the bows?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 8
chunk.description: . Why, among all the possible shapes, are circular bodies easiest to move?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 9
chunk.description: Why is it that we can move more easily and quickly things raised and drawn by means of greater circles, or similarly by means of greater trochleas and rollers?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 10
chunk.description: Why is a balance moved more easily when it is without a weight than when it has one? In the same way in the case of a wheel or anything of the kind the smaller and the leighter is more easily moved than the larger and heavier.

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 11
chunk.description: Why are heavy weights more easily carried on rollers than on carts, though the latter's wheels are larger while the circumference of rollers is small?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 12
chunk.description: Why does a missile travel further from the sling than from the hand, although in the first case the weight of the sling is added to the weight of the missile or of the stone?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 13
chunk.description: Why are the larger handles (they're levers, which others, like Pappus and Heron use to call 'roller') more easy to move round a spindle than smaller ones, and in the same way less bulky windlasses are more easily moved than thicker ones by the application of the same force?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 14
chunk.description: Why is a piece of wood of equal size more easily broken over the knee, if one holds it at equal distance far away from the knee to break it, than if one holds it by the knee and quite close to it? And similarly, if one supports the wood on the ground and then, putting the foot on it, one breaks it with the hand, why breaks it more easily if the hand is at some distance rather than if one holds it at a point close to the foot?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 15
chunk.description: Why are the stones on the seashore, which are called pebbles, round, when they are originally made from long stones and shells?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 16
chunk.description: Why are pieces of timber weaker the longer they are, and why do they bend more easily when raised; even if the short piece is for instance two cubits and light, while the long piece of a hundred cubits is thick?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 17
chunk.description: Why are great weights and bodies of considerable size split by a small wedge, and why does it exert great pressure?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 18
chunk.description: Why is it that by means of a 'trochlea' one can draw up great weights, even if the dragging force is small?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 19
chunk.description: Why is it that if one puts a large axe on a block of wood and a heavy weight on top of it, it does not cut the wood to any extent; but if one raises the axe and strikes with it, it splits it in half, even if the striker has far less weight than one placed on it and pressing it down?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 20
chunk.description: How is it that the steelyard can weigh heavy pieces of meat by means of a little weight, seeing that it is just half of a balance and that just one of the two parts is a steelyard?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 21
chunk.description: Why do dentists find it easier to take out teeth by applying the weight of the forceps than with the bare hand?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 22
chunk.description: Why can one easily break nuts without a blow in instruments made to break them? For the considerable force of motion and violence is missing. MOreover one could break them more quickly with hard and heavy nutcrackers than with wooden and light ones

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 23
chunk.description: Why is it that in a rhombus, when the extreme points travel in two movements, they do not each travel along an equal straight line, but one travels much farther than the other? Similarly why is it that the point that travels on a side, travels less than the side itself? In fact the first travels surely on the diagonal, the second travels on the longer side, and so the first makes two movements, the second just one.

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 24
chunk.description: A difficulty arises as to how it is that a greater circle, when it revolves, traces out a path of the same length as a smaller circle, if the two are concentric (the 'wheel of Aristotle'). When they are revolved separately, then the path along which they travel are in the same ratio as their respective sizes. Again, assuming that the two have the same centre, sometimes the path along which they revolve is the same size as the smaller circle would travel independently, and sometimes it is the size of the larger circle's path.

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 25
chunk.description: Why do they make beds with the length double the ends, the former being six feet or a little more and the latter three? And why do they not cord them diagonally?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 26
chunk.description: Why is it more difficult to carry long timbers on the shoulders by the end than by the middle, provided that the weight is equal in the two cases?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 27
chunk.description: Why is it that if the weight in question is extremely long, it is harder to raise it on the shoulder, even if one carries it by the middle, than if it is smaller?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 28
chunk.description: Why do men make swing-beams at wells in the way they do? For they add the weight of the lead to the wooden beam, the bucket itself having weight whether empty or full

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 29
chunk.description: Why is it that when two men carry a weight between them on a plank or something of the kind, they do not feel the pressure equally, but the nearer carrier feels it more?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 30
chunk.description: Why is it that, when men stand up, they rise by making an acute angle between the lower leg and the thigh, and between the trunk and the thigh? Otherwise they cannot rise at all.

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 31
chunk.description: Why is it easier to move that which is already moving than that which is stationary? For instance, a moving wagon is more esaily shifted than it is at the beginning.

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 32
chunk.description: Why do objects thrown ever stop travelling?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 33
chunk.description: Why does a body travel at all except by its own motion, when the discharging force does not follow and continue to push it?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 34
chunk.description: Why can neither small nor great bodies travel far when thrown, but must always bear a relation to the thrower?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Question 35
chunk.description: Why do objects which are travelling in eddying water all finish their movement in the middle?

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx

chunk.name: Appendix
chunk.description: Here there is one last problem, which is not present in the Mechanics by Aristotle

chunk.name: Premise
chunk.description: Here he says how important this question is, and how many mechanicals and philosophers have worked on it

chunk.name: question
chunk.description: Given the first and the fourth members of a mathematical proportion, how to find a couple of numbers that could act as the central members of that proportion

chunk.name: explanation
chunk.description: xxx
